Description: Body sherd of large Corinthian black-figured pottery alabastron; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of panther standing to right (neck, breast with added red, forelegs, and belly remaining), facing goat grazing to left (head and left foreleg remaining); incised dots and blobs as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 218)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 53, no. A9, p. 60, no. A29, pl. XLV)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.145) (Phase 1)
